study_identification.title: Developmental trajectories of neuroanatomical alterations associated with the 16p11.2 Copy Number Variations

study_characteristics.study_objective: To characterize age-related effects of 16p11.2 copy number variants on brain structure across childhood, adolescence, and early adulthood using a large normative developmental dataset for accurate age adjustment and to determine when these alterations appear and whether they evolve with age.

dataset_name.Answer: NIHPD (NIH MRI study of normal brain development)
dataset_name.Reason: The normative reference dataset is clearly stated as NIHPD Objective 1 data, which was used to model age- and sex-related brain growth trajectories.
dataset_name.Supporting Text: As normative reference data for brain growth, we used the multi-site longitudinal data from Objective 1 (i.e. initial time-point for enrolment from 4.5 to 18.5 years) of the publicly available NIHPD project (Evans and Brain Development Cooperative, 2006).

hc_n.Reason: The NIHPD normative model was built using data from 339 children who were scanned longitudinally, resulting in 874 total scans.
hc_n.Supporting Text: The normative model (Aubert-Broche et al., 2011) used data from 339 children (179 females and 160 males), scanned longitudinally at 2 or 3 time points, with approximately 24 months between scans and mean age at first scan of 11.0 years, for a total of 874 scans.

hc_age.Answer: mean 11.0 years at first scan; enrollment range 4.5-18.5 years
hc_age.Reason: The mean age at first scan and enrollment age range are explicitly stated for the NIHPD cohort.
hc_age.Supporting Text: The normative model (Aubert-Broche et al., 2011) used data from 339 children (179 females and 160 males), scanned longitudinally at 2 or 3 time points, with approximately 24 months between scans and mean age at first scan of 11.0 years, for a total of 874 scans. ... multi-site longitudinal data from Objective 1 (i.e. initial time-point for enrolment from 4.5 to 18.5 years)

hc_sex.Reason: The number of females and males in the NIHPD normative cohort is clearly stated. Percentages are calculated from the provided counts.
hc_sex.Supporting Text: The normative model (Aubert-Broche et al., 2011) used data from 339 children (179 females and 160 males)

imaging_modality.Reason: The NIHPD protocol included whole-brain 3D T1-weighted RF-spoiled gradient echo sequences. For the 16p11.2 dataset (not the normative cohort), T1-weighted MPRAGE sequences were used.
imaging_modality.Supporting Text: Scans of the NIHPD controls were obtained at 6 study centers with 1.5 Tesla MRI scanners from General Electric or Siemens Medical Systems. The MRI protocol included a whole-brain, 3D T1w RF-spoiled gradient echo sequence (1-mm-thick sagittal partitions, TR 22-25 msec, TE 10-11 msec, excitation pulse angle 30°, Field Of View 160-180 mm).

analysis_level.Reason: The study performed both ROI-level analysis (segmented brain regions including whole-brain, lobes, and subcortical structures) and voxel-level analysis using Tensor-Based Morphometry (TBM).
analysis_level.Supporting Text: We normalized volumes of segmented brain regions as well as volumes of each voxel defined by tensor-based morphometry. ... Whole-brain, individual lobes, thalamus, putamen, caudate, globus pallidus and ventricular volumes were calculated ... To investigate brain alterations beyond a priori specified anatomical regions of interest, we used Tensor Based Morphometry (TBM), which enables a whole-brain voxel-by-voxel statistical analysis

preprocessing_pipeline.Answer: Denoising; N3 intensity inhomogeneity correction; intensity normalization by histogram matching to ICBM152; 9-parameter linear registration to ICBM152; BEaST brain extraction; ANIMAL nonlinear registration; TBM with 10 mm FWHM Gaussian smoothing; Jacobian determinant calculation
preprocessing_pipeline.Reason: The preprocessing pipeline is described in detail in the Image processing section, including specific algorithms and parameters.
preprocessing_pipeline.Supporting Text: The preprocessing steps applied to the native T1w images were (1) denoising, (2) intensity inhomogeneity correction using the N3 algorithm (Sled et al., 1998), and (3) intensity normalization by histogram matching to the ICBM152 template (Fonov et al., 2011). A hierarchical 9-parameter linear registration based on an intensity cross-correlation similarity measure was performed between the T1w images and the ICBM152 template ... Brain extraction was achieved using the Brain Extraction based on nonlocal Segmentation Technique (BEaST) (Eskildsen et al., 2012) ... Subsequently, images were non-linearly registered using the Automated Nonlinear Image Matching and Anatomical Labelling (ANIMAL) algorithm (Collins et al., 1995) ... A 3D Gaussian filter with FWHM of 10 mm was applied to the resulting inverted deformation grids. The Jacobian determinant of the deformation field was computed for every voxel, log-transformed

quality_checking.Reason: Quality control was performed for both NIHPD and 16p11.2 datasets. NIHPD included only subjects passing QC, and 16p11.2 data underwent thorough visual QC for motion artifacts.
quality_checking.Supporting Text: Only subjects that passed quality control were included. ... Because our analysis covers a broad age range, there is increased risk of systematic age-dependent motion artefacts. We performed a thorough visual quality control check looking for evidence of motion artefacts.

quality_checking_detail.Answer: NIHPD: Only subjects that passed quality control were included (specific metrics and exclusion numbers not reported). 16p11.2 dataset: Thorough visual quality control check for motion artifacts; broad age range increases risk of age-dependent motion artifacts.
quality_checking_detail.Reason: Quality checking is mentioned and described as thorough, but specific metrics (e.g., thresholds, automated QC measures) and exclusion counts are not provided.
quality_checking_detail.Supporting Text: Only subjects that passed quality control were included. ... Because our analysis covers a broad age range, there is increased risk of systematic age-dependent motion artefacts. We performed a thorough visual quality control check looking for evidence of motion artefacts.

site_effect_handling.Reason: Scanner/site effects were tested as a fixed effect in the normative mixed-effects model but found non-significant. Additionally, a linear correction for protocol differences (1.5T vs 3T, single vs multi-echo) was applied to align 16p11.2 controls to NIHPD norms.
site_effect_handling.Supporting Text: During model selection, a fixed effect for individual scanner was tested but found to be not significant and the model was associated with a higher Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC). ... After normalization of the 16p11.2 controls, we observed that certain regions required small additional corrections attributed to differences in scanning parameters between the NIHPD and the 16p11.2 data (e.g. 1.5 T vs 3T scans). We estimated a linear model that included Age and Intercept (i.e. bias and slope) for the Z-scored segmented volumes and the voxel-wise log-transformed Jacobian determinants of the 16p11.2 control data.

site_effect_handling_detail.Answer: Normative model: Scanner fixed effect tested but excluded due to non-significance and higher BIC. Linear correction: After Z-scoring with NIHPD norms, 16p11.2 control data were adjusted using a linear model (age + intercept) to correct for protocol differences (1.5T vs 3T; single vs multi-echo). This correction was applied to CNV carriers as well. The intercepts/slopes for correction were: total brain -0.68/-0.04; gray matter -0.11/-0.1; white matter 0.42/0.05; lateral ventricle -0.32/-0.02. Previous multisite analysis (Martin-Brevet et al., 2018) showed CNV-associated regions were not attributable to multisite artifacts.
site_effect_handling_detail.Reason: The handling of scanner/site effects is described in detail, including the rationale for excluding scanner from the mixed model, the linear correction procedure, and citation of prior validation that multisite effects did not confound CNV findings.
site_effect_handling_detail.Supporting Text: During model selection, a fixed effect for individual scanner was tested but found to be not significant and the model was associated with a higher Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC). ... We estimated a linear model that included Age and Intercept (i.e. bias and slope) for the Z-scored segmented volumes and the voxel-wise log-transformed Jacobian determinants of the 16p11.2 control data. The parameters of this linear model were used to adjust the 16p11.2 control dataset in order to obtain a mean Z-score of 0 for all ages. ... The same adjustment was applied to the CNV carrier groups. ... The intercepts and the slopes were, respectively -0.68/-0.04 for the total brain volume; -0.11/-0.1 for the gray matter volume (GM); 0.42/0.05 for the white matter volume (WM) and -0.32/-0.02 for the lateral ventricle (LV). ... Extensive analyses on the potential effect of these scanning sites and protocols were performed in a previous study showing that none of the regions associated with the 16p11.2 deletion or duplication could be attributed to artefacts introduced by the multisite analyses (Martin-Brevet et al., 2018).

model_origin.Reason: The normative growth model was previously developed using NIHPD data (Aubert-Broche et al., 2013) and applied to the 16p11.2 dataset in the current study.
model_origin.Supporting Text: We (Aubert-Broche et al., 2013) have previously developed a longitudinal image processing pipeline and Z-scoring method to adjust for age- and sex effects on brain growth trajectories using the NIH MRI study of normal brain development (NIHPD) (Evans and Brain Development Cooperative, 2006). ... In the present study, we use similar methods to Z-score a cross-sectional 16p11.2 dataset

model_origin_detail.Answer: Pre-trained normative model developed by Aubert-Broche et al. (2013) using NIHPD longitudinal data from 339 children (179 females, 160 males) scanned at 2-3 time points (874 total scans). Model uses mixed-effects framework to estimate age- and sex-related growth trajectories. See Aubert-Broche et al. (2013) NeuroImage for full details.
model_origin_detail.Reason: The study provides clear information about the pre-trained model source, including the dataset (NIHPD), sample size, and reference to the original publication.
model_origin_detail.Supporting Text: We (Aubert-Broche et al., 2013) have previously developed a longitudinal image processing pipeline and Z-scoring method to adjust for age- and sex effects on brain growth trajectories using the NIH MRI study of normal brain development (NIHPD) (Evans and Brain Development Cooperative, 2006). ... The normative model (Aubert-Broche et al., 2011) used data from 339 children (179 females and 160 males), scanned longitudinally at 2 or 3 time points, with approximately 24 months between scans and mean age at first scan of 11.0 years, for a total of 874 scans.

modeling_method.Answer: Linear mixed-effects model with quadratic age function
modeling_method.Reason: The normative modeling approach is explicitly described as using mixed-effects models with both linear and quadratic age terms plus sex, with random effects for intercept and age slope.
modeling_method.Supporting Text: Mixed-effect models were used since it is appropriate to estimate growth in longitudinal studies that take repeated measures from the same individuals over time. ... individual profiles suggest modeling brain growth as a quadratic function over time: we included both linear and quadratic effects of age in the fixed effects structure. Age was not divided into bins, but was considered as a continuous variable and was centered at 13 years - the mean age of NIHPD cohort. Linear effect of sex was also included in the fixed terms ... The mixed-effects model that best fits the normative data is: Vol_i = β_0 + γ_0 + (β_1 + γ_1)(Age_i - 13) + β_2(Age_i - 13)^2 + β_3*Sex_i + ε_i

software_tool.Reason: The software and specific package used for mixed-effects modeling are explicitly stated.
software_tool.Supporting Text: All analyses were conducted using R 3.4.0 (The R Project for Statistical Computing; http://www.R-project.org/). The mixed-effect models were built using the nlme package.

response_variable.Answer: Global volumes (total brain volume, gray matter volume, white matter volume, lateral ventricle volume); subcortical volumes (thalamus, putamen, caudate, globus pallidus); lobar volumes; voxel-wise log-Jacobian determinants (TBM)
response_variable.Reason: The response variables are clearly described for both ROI-level and voxel-level analyses.
response_variable.Supporting Text: Whole-brain, individual lobes, thalamus, putamen, caudate, globus pallidus and ventricular volumes were calculated, with the right and left volumes combined for analysis. ... The Jacobian determinant of the deformation field was computed for every voxel, log-transformed and used as a surrogate of the local volume difference between each subject and the ICBM152 template.

predictor_variables.Reason: The predictor variables in the normative model are explicitly stated, including both linear and quadratic age terms and sex.
predictor_variables.Supporting Text: we included both linear and quadratic effects of age in the fixed effects structure. Age was not divided into bins, but was considered as a continuous variable and was centered at 13 years - the mean age of NIHPD cohort. Linear effect of sex was also included in the fixed terms ... The mixed-effects model that best fits the normative data is: Vol_i = β_0 + γ_0 + (β_1 + γ_1)(Age_i - 13) + β_2(Age_i - 13)^2 + β_3*Sex_i + ε_i

predictor_effects.Answer: Fixed effects: Age (linear), Age^2 (quadratic), Sex. Random effects: Intercept (γ_0) and Age slope (γ_1) per subject.
predictor_effects.Reason: The model specification clearly indicates which terms are fixed and which are random effects.
predictor_effects.Supporting Text: we included both linear and quadratic effects of age in the fixed effects structure. ... Linear effect of sex was also included in the fixed terms ... The mixed-effects model that best fits the normative data is: Vol_i = β_0 + γ_0 + (β_1 + γ_1)(Age_i - 13) + β_2(Age_i - 13)^2 + β_3*Sex_i + ε_i where ... β_0, γ_0 are the intercept for the fixed and random terms, β_1, β_2, β_3 are the fixed effects coefficients and are identical for all subjects, γ_1 is a random effect coefficient

nm_vldtn_handle_ns.Reason: The study addresses several nuisance structures: (1) Protocol/scanner differences between NIHPD (1.5T) and 16p11.2 (3T, multi/single-echo) are handled via linear correction after Z-scoring; (2) Scanner fixed effect tested in normative model but excluded (non-significant); (3) Multisite effects in 16p11.2 previously validated as not confounding CNV findings; (4) Quadratic age modeling captures nonlinearity; (5) Random effects for subject-level intercept and age slope account for within-subject correlation in longitudinal NIHPD data. However, no explicit discussion of variance heterogeneity across sites or age, and no harmonization methods like ComBat. Some residual deviations in 16p11.2 controls (e.g., putamen, medial frontal cortex Z-scores -0.88 to 1.09) suggest incomplete nuisance correction.
nm_vldtn_handle_ns.Supporting Text: During model selection, a fixed effect for individual scanner was tested but found to be not significant and the model was associated with a higher Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC). ... We estimated a linear model that included Age and Intercept (i.e. bias and slope) for the Z-scored segmented volumes and the voxel-wise log-transformed Jacobian determinants of the 16p11.2 control data. The parameters of this linear model were used to adjust the 16p11.2 control dataset in order to obtain a mean Z-score of 0 for all ages. ... Regarding voxel-based mean Z-scores, 16p11.2 CTRL also show deviations from the baseline of NIHPD controls, in particular in the left putamen and the medial frontal cortex (Z-scores between -0.88 and 1.09) (Supplementary Figure 5.A). ... Extensive analyses on the potential effect of these scanning sites and protocols were performed in a previous study showing that none of the regions associated with the 16p11.2 deletion or duplication could be attributed to artefacts introduced by the multisite analyses (Martin-Brevet et al., 2018).

nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.Reason: The normative model was trained on NIHPD longitudinal data (874 scans from 339 children with 2-3 timepoints each), which includes non-independent repeated measures from the same individuals. The mixed-effects framework with random effects for intercept and age slope explicitly accounts for within-subject correlation. Model fit is demonstrated (Supplementary Figure 3 shows mixed-effects fit on total brain volume).
nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.Supporting Text: Mixed-effect models were used since it is appropriate to estimate growth in longitudinal studies that take repeated measures from the same individuals over time. It accounts for the within-participant correlation and for varying numbers of measurements for each participant. ... The normative model (Aubert-Broche et al., 2011) used data from 339 children (179 females and 160 males), scanned longitudinally at 2 or 3 time points, with approximately 24 months between scans and mean age at first scan of 11.0 years, for a total of 874 scans. ... Supplementary Fig. 3 shows the resulting Mixed-Effects fit on Total Brain Volume for the NIHPD population.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_indep.Reason: The study validates the normative model by applying it to an independent control group (105 controls from the 16p11.2 cohort scanned with different protocols). After Z-scoring with NIHPD norms and linear correction for protocol differences, 16p11.2 controls show mean Z-scores near zero for global volumes and voxel-level measures, confirming model generalization. Supplementary Figure 4 shows control normalization before/after adjustment, and Supplementary Figure 5.A shows voxel-based mean Z-scores for controls are close to baseline with only minor deviations (Z-scores -0.88 to 1.09 in putamen and medial frontal cortex).
nm_vldtn_same_domain_indep.Supporting Text: After normalization of the 16p11.2 controls, we observed that certain regions required small additional corrections attributed to differences in scanning parameters between the NIHPD and the 16p11.2 data (e.g. 1.5 T vs 3T scans). We estimated a linear model that included Age and Intercept (i.e. bias and slope) for the Z-scored segmented volumes and the voxel-wise log-transformed Jacobian determinants of the 16p11.2 control data. The parameters of this linear model were used to adjust the 16p11.2 control dataset in order to obtain a mean Z-score of 0 for all ages. ... Supplementary Fig. 4 shows a linear fit of the controls before and after normalization. ... Regarding voxel-based mean Z-scores, 16p11.2 CTRL also show deviations from the baseline of NIHPD controls, in particular in the left putamen and the medial frontal cortex (Z-scores between -0.88 and 1.09) (Supplementary Figure 5.A).

nm_vldtn_diff_domain.Reason: The study does not validate the normative model on data from a completely different domain or external cohort. Validation is limited to: (1) within-domain non-independent data (NIHPD longitudinal scans) and (2) within-domain independent data (16p11.2 controls from the same study scanned with different protocols). No external datasets or entirely different populations (e.g., from other studies, countries, or clinical settings) are used for validation.
nm_vldtn_diff_domain.Supporting Text: No text explicitly describes validation on a different-domain dataset. The study applies NIHPD norms to 16p11.2 data but both are from controlled research settings. The paper states: 'In the present study, we use similar methods to Z-score a cross-sectional 16p11.2 dataset (56 deletion carriers, 19 duplication carriers, 105 control individuals, including data on 8 individuals not analyzed in previous studies)' and 'After normalization of the 16p11.2 controls, we observed that certain regions required small additional corrections attributed to differences in scanning parameters between the NIHPD and the 16p11.2 data (e.g. 1.5 T vs 3T scans).' This indicates the validation is within the same research domain with protocol adjustments, not a different-domain validation.

clinical_dataset.Reason: The clinical groups (deletion and duplication carriers) are from two cohorts explicitly named in the paper.
clinical_dataset.Supporting Text: Cross-sectional data was acquired in 2 different cohorts (the European -EU 16p11.2 consortium and the Simons VIP -SVIP study in North America) of 180 individuals (Simons Vip, 2012; Martin-Brevet et al., 2018). ... This included 56 16p11.2 BP4-5 deletion carriers (DEL) from American (n = 42) and European (n = 14) cohorts; 19 duplication carriers (DUP) from American (n = 15) and European (n = 4) cohorts

diseases_studied.Answer: 16p11.2 copy number variants (deletions and duplications) associated with neurodevelopmental disorders including Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), Schizophrenia, Intellectual Disability, ADHD, Language disorders, Learning disorders, Developmental coordination disorder, and others
diseases_studied.Reason: The study focuses on 16p11.2 CNV carriers who have high risk for neurodevelopmental disorders. Specific diagnoses in the sample are detailed in Supplementary Table 1, including ASD, ADHD, intellectual disability, language/learning disorders, mood disorders, anxiety disorders, and others.
diseases_studied.Supporting Text: Deletion and duplication carriers have a 10-fold increased risk of developing autism spectrum disorders (ASD) (Moreno-De-Luca et al., 2013), and duplication (but not deletion) carriers a 10-fold increased risk for schizophrenia (Marshall et al., 2017). ... Supplementary Table 1 shows neuropsychiatric diagnoses: A total of 53 of 56 deletion carriers (95%) had at least one psychiatric diagnosis ... 15 of 19 duplication carriers (79%) had at least one psychiatric diagnosis. Diagnoses include: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, Intellectual Disability, Language and communication disorders, Phonological disorder, Learning disorders, Autistic Spectrum Disorder, Developmental coordination disorder, Enuresis and encopresis disorders, Oppositional-defiant-disorder, Mood disorder, Anxiety Disorders, Stereotypic Movement disorder, Tic disorder, Borderline Intellectual Functioning.

clinical_groups_n.Answer: DEL (16p11.2 deletion carriers): 56; DUP (16p11.2 duplication carriers): 19
clinical_groups_n.Reason: Sample sizes for deletion and duplication groups are clearly stated in Table 1 and throughout the text.
clinical_groups_n.Supporting Text: This included 56 16p11.2 BP4-5 deletion carriers (DEL) from American (n = 42) and European (n = 14) cohorts; 19 duplication carriers (DUP) from American (n = 15) and European (n = 4) cohorts); and 105 controls (CTRL) ... Data was analyzed for 56 DEL, 19 DUP, 105 familial and unrelated CTRL with ages ranging from 4.5 to 23 years. Table 1: N: DEL 56, DUP 19

clinical_groups_age.Answer: DEL: mean 11.26 (SD 3.62); range 6.33-22.33 years. DUP: mean 12.29 (SD 4.87); range 5.00-20.33 years
clinical_groups_age.Reason: Age statistics for both clinical groups are provided in Table 1.
clinical_groups_age.Supporting Text: Table 1: Age (years) - DEL: Mean (SD) 11.26 (3.62); range (min-max) 6.33-22.33. DUP: Mean (SD) 12.29 (4.87); range 5-20.33

clinical_groups_sex.Reason: Sex distribution for both clinical groups is provided in Table 1. Percentages calculated from the provided counts.

deviation_metric.Reason: The study uses Z-scores computed from the NIHPD normative model to quantify deviation from typical development for both global and voxel-level measures.
deviation_metric.Supporting Text: Using the mean and the estimated standard deviation of the model we were able to compute Z-scores for the global volumes of the brain as well as for each voxel independently, for the 16p11.2 and control participants using the following formula: z = (x-x̄)/s. ... Deletion carriers have higher volume than controls for total brain (mean Z-score = 1.165, p-value < 0.0001), gray (mean Z-score = 0.414, p-value = 0.00433) and white matter volumes (mean Z-score = 0.693, p-value < 0.0001)

association_analysis.Answer: Linear models with genetic status (DEL, DUP, CTRL) as covariate applied to age/sex-adjusted Z-scores. Interaction terms (age*sex, age*group) tested. Bonferroni correction for global volumes (8 comparisons). False Discovery Rate (FDR q<0.05) correction for voxel-wise analyses. Anatomical labeling using neuromorphometric atlas.
association_analysis.Reason: Statistical methods for testing group differences are clearly described, including linear models, interaction testing, and multiple comparison corrections.
association_analysis.Supporting Text: We used a linear model introducing genetic status as a covariate to investigate the effect of the DEL and DUP on normalized segmented regional and voxel-level adjusted Z-scores volumes. The following interaction terms were tested: age*sex and age*group. We extracted the p-values from the linear models. Results for the 4 global volumes are Bonferroni corrected for 8 simultaneous comparisons (4 × DEL vs CTRL and 4 × DUP vs CTRL). Results for the voxel-wise analysis are adjusted using Benjamini-Hochberg False Discovery Rate -FDR correction (q < 0.05) (Benjamini and Hochberg, 1995). Regions with significant differences were anatomically labeled using the neuromorphometric atlas

key_findings_brief.Answer: 16p11.2 deletions and duplications show mirror-effect brain alterations (deletions increased, duplications decreased volumes) that are present at 4.5 years and remain stable without age-related changes through 23 years, highlighting early-onset neuroimaging endophenotypes that persist across development.
key_findings_brief.Reason: This summary captures the main findings stated in the abstract and discussion.
key_findings_brief.Supporting Text: Results show that the total intracranial volumes, the global gray and white matter volumes are respectively higher and lower in deletion and duplication carriers compared to control subjects at 4.5 years of age. These differences remain stable through childhood, adolescence and adulthood until 23 years of age (range: 0.5 to 1.0 Z-score). ... All large effect-size voxel-based differences are present at 4.5 years and seem to remain stable until the age of 23. Our results highlight the stability of a neuroimaging endophenotype over 2 decades during which neurodevelopmental symptoms evolve at a rapid pace.

key_findings_detailed.Answer: 16p11.2 CNVs show inverse gene dosage effects on brain structure. Deletions show increased volumes (Z-scores): total brain +1.165 (p<0.0001), gray matter +0.414 (p=0.00433), white matter +0.693 (p<0.0001). Duplications show decreased volumes (Z-scores): total brain -1.17 (p=0.0001), gray matter -0.631 (p=0.00272), white matter -0.53 (p=0.0018), lateral ventricles increased +1.629 (p<0.0001). Regional voxel-based analysis (TBM) identified mirror effects (DEL>CTRL>DUP) in bilateral calcarine cortex, insula, left transverse temporal gyrus, planum temporale, parietal operculum, and frontal/occipital white matter. Deletion-specific increases found in cuneus, anterior cingulate, posterior orbital and inferior frontal gyri. Deletion-specific decreases in bilateral cerebellum, middle cingulate, pallidum, putamen, precentral/postcentral gyri, fusiform, middle/inferior temporal gyri, supplementary motor cortex, gyrus rectus, left accumbens and angular gyrus. Duplication-specific decrease in occipital fusiform gyrus. Representative regions show effect sizes of Z = ±0.7 to ±1.6 across the full age range (4.5-23 years). No significant age*group or age*sex interactions were detected for any global or voxel-level measure, indicating alterations are established by 4.5 years and remain stable thereafter. Findings replicate previous results from Martin-Brevet et al. (2018) showing insula affected in both CNVs (mirror fashion) and calcarine cortex, temporal and precentral gyri altered in deletions.
key_findings_detailed.Reason: Detailed numerical results are provided throughout the Results section, including Z-scores, p-values, and effect-size ranges for global and regional findings, as well as description of stability across age.
key_findings_detailed.Supporting Text: 16p11.2 carriers present an inverse gene dosage effect for most of the global metrics. Deletion carriers have higher volume than controls for total brain (mean Z-score = 1.165, p-value < 0.0001), gray (mean Z-score = 0.414, p-value = 0.00433) and white matter volumes (mean Z-score = 0.693, p-value < 0.0001) (Fig. 1). Duplication carriers show the opposite effect, with lower total brain (mean Z-score = -1.17, p-value = 0.0001), gray (mean Z-score = -0.631, p-value = 0.00272) and white matter volume (mean Z-score = -0.53, p-value = 0.0018) compared to controls. Duplication carriers have larger lateral ventricles, with mean Z-score of 1.629 (p-value < 0.0001). We do not observe any interaction between the effects of genetic groups and age nor between sex and age. ... The TBM analysis identifies several brain regions associated with an inverse gene dosage effect: Deletion carriers have significantly higher Jacobian determinants than controls, whereas duplication have significantly lower values (i.e. DEL > CTRL > DUP) in the following regions: bilateral calcarine cortex, insula, left transverse temporal gyrus, planum temporale and parietal operculum. ... Fig. 3 shows this complete lack of age-related effects for the top 8 regional differences with the largest effect sizes. Whatever the age, the DEL have volume Z-scores of 0.7 and 1 for the anterior insula and the calcarine cortex respectively, and the DUP have volume Z-scores of -0.9 and -1.2 on the same structures. DEL have volume Z-scores of 0.9 and 0.7 for the posterior orbital and anterior cingulate gyri respectively; they have the most negative volume Z-scores: 1.6 and -1.1 for the cerebellar hemispheres and the fusiform gyrus. DUP have also high volume Z-scores for the lateral ventricle and inferior temporal gyrus, 1.6 and 0.9 respectively.

key_limitations.Answer: Technical differences in acquisition (1.5T NIHPD vs 3T 16p11.2; multi-center variability) may affect registration quality. Future normative curves should incorporate additional variables (ancestry, field strength, demographics). Broad age range may introduce age-dependent motion artifacts, though thorough QC was performed and no age-related findings emerged. Limited power to detect small age-related changes (smallest detectable: DEL 0.07-0.12 Z-score/year; DUP 0.09-0.16 Z-score/year). Uncertainty for lower age range; larger sample of younger participants needed. Results may not generalize to CNV carriers with extreme obesity or severe ASD unable to complete scanning. Cohort representative of broader 16p11.2 IQ and psychiatric symptoms but sample size limits investigation of onset at very young ages.
key_limitations.Reason: Limitations are explicitly discussed in the Discussion section, covering technical, statistical, and generalizability issues.
key_limitations.Supporting Text: The main limitations of the present study stem from the technical differences in acquisition, which include the aforementioned 1.5 T and 3 T fields used in the NIHPD and 16p11.2 datasets respectively. In addition, the 16p11.2 is a multi-center database, further increasing the variability in the scans. These acquisition differences can affect the quality of the non-linear registrations from which the Jacobians are calculated. Future work should look into improving the current normative growth curves by further considering additional potential sources of variation including, but not limited to, ancestry, MRI field strength and other demographic variables. The broad age range could have introduced systematic age-dependent motion artefacts leading to spurious findings. This is however unlikely due to the absence of any age-related findings in our analysis and the thorough quality check performed on the dataset. Our power to observe age-related differences was constrained by sample size. We estimate that the smallest detectable change with power = 0.80, and alpha = 0.05 in the duplication carriers for whole brain is 0.16 Z-score per year, for gray matter 0.10/year and 0.09/year for white matter. For deletions, we could detect 0.12 Z-score per year for whole brain, 0.09/year for gray matter and 0.07/year for white matter. There is also uncertainty for the lower age range of our study. A larger sample of younger participants is required to further investigate the presence of these findings at 4 years of age. Results may not generalize to 16p11.2 CNV carriers with extreme obesity or severe ASD symptoms that were unable to complete the scanning session. Nevertheless, our cohort is highly representative of the Intelligence quotient and psychiatric symptoms observed in our broader sample of 16p11.2 CNV carriers (D'Angelo et al., 2016).

application_notes.Answer: This study demonstrates that neuroimaging alterations associated with genetically defined neurodevelopmental risk (16p11.2 CNVs) are present early and stable across development, contrasting with behavioral/symptom trajectories that evolve rapidly during the same period. The stability of the neuroimaging endophenotype from 4.5 to 23 years suggests brain alterations may precede or underlie symptom emergence and evolution. Results are consistent with findings in idiopathic ASD and other genetic syndromes (Fragile X, 22q11.2 deletion) showing early-established brain differences. Mouse models of 16p11.2 deletion show alterations in insula and striatum at postnatal day 7 (equivalent to prenatal period in humans), suggesting very early developmental onset. The normalization approach using large external normative datasets enables study across broad age ranges despite nonlinear brain growth. Data in neonates and toddlers will be needed to pinpoint exact onset timing of alterations.
application_notes.Reason: The Discussion section places findings in broader context of neurodevelopmental trajectories, compares to other disorders/syndromes, and discusses implications for understanding brain-behavior relationships and timing of alterations.
application_notes.Supporting Text: Our results highlight the stability of a neuroimaging endophenotype over 2 decades during which neurodevelopmental symptoms evolve at a rapid pace. ... Recently, a large cross-sectional neuroimaging study in idiopathic ASD (van Rooij et al., 2018) identified differences in subcortical volumes that are stable across the entire age range of the study from 2 to 64 years of age. ... Longitudinal studies in idiopathic ASD showed that subcortical alterations and increased total and regional cortical surface area present at 2 years of age remain stable at the age of 4 years (Hazlett et al., 2011). ... In Fragile X syndrome, larger brain volumes are stable between 2 and 5 years of age (Hazlett et al., 2012). Similar to observations in ASD, neuroimaging studies of 22q11.2 deletion carriers suggest that alterations in subcortical and surface area are stable from 5 to 65 years ... Investigating individuals who carry the same genetic mutation is a powerful strategy to study alterations of brain growth trajectories associated with molecular mechanisms underlying neurodevelopmental disorders. ... The brain differences are reminiscent of MRI studies in several 16p11.2 deletion mice models which have identified alterations in the insula and striatum at 7 days, equivalent to a prenatal period in humans (Portmann et al., 2014). Data in neonates and toddlers will be required to advance our understanding on the onset of these alterations.

general_notes.Answer: This study uses a pre-trained normative model (NIHPD) to investigate 16p11.2 CNVs, a specific genetic condition rather than a clinically diagnosed disorder. The 16p11.2 cohort includes both CNV carriers and 105 familial/unrelated controls for comparison and normalization validation. Control subjects include 34 non-carrier first-degree relatives of CNV carriers and 71 volunteers without family history of neurodevelopmental disorders. The study included 4 controls, 3 duplications, and 1 deletion carrier not in previous publication (Martin-Brevet et al., 2018). NIHPD ancestry: Caucasian >70%, African-American 11%, Asian 2%, Other 15%. 16p11.2 cohort ancestry (where known): Caucasian >70% (50 DEL, 35 CTRL, 15 DUP), African-American 9.38% (12 CTRL only), Asian 1.56% (1 DEL, 1 CTRL), Other 10.94%. Ancestry unknown for 3 CNV carriers and 49 controls. Neuropsychiatric diagnoses high in CNV carriers: 95% of deletions (53/56) and 79% of duplications (15/19) had ≥1 diagnosis; 35% of familial controls (12/34) had ≥1 diagnosis. Most common diagnoses in deletions: phonological disorder (41), developmental coordination disorder (16), language/communication disorders (14), ADHD (12), learning disorders (12), ASD (9). Non-verbal IQ significantly lower in CNV carriers: DEL mean 87 (SD 14), DUP mean 77 (SD 19) vs CTRL mean 108 (SD 12). Deletion carriers significantly younger than controls (t=-4.5272, p=1.347e-05). Images acquired at 7 sites using 3T scanners (Philips Achieva, Siemens Prisma Syngo, Siemens Tim Trio). Imaging protocol: 3 sites multi-echo MPRAGE (126 participants: 38 DEL, 12 DUP, 76 CTRL), 4 sites single-echo MPRAGE (54 participants: 18 DEL, 7 DUP, 29 CTRL). Scan parameter (multi/single echo) included as covariate in analyses. NIHPD scans: 1.5T (GE or Siemens) at 6 centers, T1w RF-spoiled gradient echo (TR 22-25ms, TE 10-11ms, flip 30°, FOV 160-180mm). Supplementary materials include detailed neuropsychiatric diagnoses (Supplementary Table 1), acquisition parameters (Supplementary Table 2), anatomical coordinates of significant clusters (Supplementary Table 3), and figures showing age distributions, mixed-effects fits, normalization procedures, and voxel-based Z-score maps (Supplementary Figures 1-5).
general_notes.Reason: Additional contextual information extracted from throughout the paper and supplementary materials provides important details about the cohort composition, ancestry, psychiatric comorbidities, IQ, imaging parameters, and supplementary analyses.
general_notes.Supporting Text: Various excerpts from Table 1, Supplementary Tables 1-2, methods sections describing participants, imaging protocols, and results figures.
